key_findings: Implement dark and light mode support using the CSS media query '@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark)' to automatically detect user preferences.
Utilize CSS custom properties (variables) to define color schemes, allowing for easier maintenance and updates across your stylesheets.
Ensure that all color contrasts meet accessibility standards (WCAG) in both light and dark modes to provide a better user experience for all users.
Test your application in both dark and light modes to identify any UI elements that may not render correctly or become unreadable due to color changes.
Consider providing a manual toggle for users to switch between dark and light modes, storing their preference in local storage for a personalized experience.
Use semantic color names in your CSS (e.g., 'background-color-light', 'background-color-dark') to improve code readability and maintainability.
Be cautious of images and media that may not adapt well to color scheme changes; consider providing alternative assets or styles for each mode.
Regularly update your stylesheets to include new color variables and ensure that all components are styled consistently across both modes.
Monitor performance implications when using CSS custom properties, as excessive use can lead to rendering issues in older browsers.
Implement fallback styles for browsers that do not support the 'prefers-color-scheme' media query to ensure a consistent experience across all platforms.

code_examples.description: CSS for light and dark themes using custom properties.
JavaScript to toggle between light and dark modes.

best_practices: Practice 1: Use CSS variables for colors to simplify theme management.
Practice 2: Provide a toggle switch for users to manually select their preferred theme.
Practice 3: Respect user preferences by checking system settings with media queries.
Practice 4: Ensure that all text and UI elements maintain adequate contrast in both themes.
Practice 5: Use smooth transitions for a better user experience when switching themes.
common_pitfalls: Pitfall 1: Neglecting accessibility; ensure color contrast meets WCAG standards.
Pitfall 2: Hardcoding colors instead of using variables, making theme management difficult.
Pitfall 3: Failing to test across different browsers and devices, leading to inconsistent user experiences.
Pitfall 4: Not saving user preferences, causing frustration when the theme resets.
implementation_patterns: Pattern 1: Use CSS custom properties for defining theme colors and apply them throughout your stylesheets.
Pattern 2: Use a JavaScript function to toggle the theme and update local storage accordingly.
Pattern 3: Implement a media query to automatically apply dark mode based on user system preferences.
performance_considerations: Consideration 1: Minimize reflows and repaints by using CSS transitions for theme changes.
Consideration 2: Use efficient selectors and avoid excessive CSS rules to enhance rendering performance.
security_considerations: Security tip 1: Ensure that user preferences stored in local storage do not expose sensitive information.
